data.title: Root node
data.solution:
is_root = dict()
n = int(input())

for i in range(n):
    x, y = input().split()

    if x not in is_root:
        is_root[x] = True
    is_root[y] = False

solution = sorted(list(filter(lambda x: is_root[x], is_root)))

print(" ".join(solution) if len(solution) > 0 else "none")
data.statement:
The goal is to find root nodes if they exist.
A root node is a node which doesn't have a parent node. No node links to it.

Given all the links between nodes, you must return root nodes or {{none}}.

A node is named by a capital letter.
Links are given by two nodes space separated. "X Y" represent a link <<from>> node X <<to>> node Y.

Example: "A B", "B C"
We can represent the structure like this : A -> B -> C
So the answer is A because no node links to it.

data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read parent:word(1) child:word(1)
write root nodes
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[n]] for the number of links.
<<Next [[n]] lines:>> Two capital letters [[parent]] and [[child]] representing a link from node [[parent]] to node [[child]].
data.outputDescription: Root nodes sorted alphabetically space separated or {{none}}

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The goal is to find root nodes if they exist.
A root node is a node which doesn't have a parent node. No node links to it.

Given all the links between nodes, you must return root nodes or none.

A node is named by a capital letter.
Links are given by two nodes space separated. "X Y" represent a link from node X to node Y.

Example: "A B", "B C"
We can represent the structure like this : A -> B -> C
So the answer is A because no node links to it.
Input
Line 1: An integer n for the number of links.
Next n lines: Two capital letters parent and child representing a link from node parent to node child.
Output
Root nodes sorted alphabetically space separated or none
Constraints
1 <= n <= 100
parent, child ∈ [A - Z]
Example
Input
3
A B
B C
C D
Output
A
